s.text: The town, we can surmise from this, has come a long way.
The town, we can surmise from this, has come a long way.
The town, we can surmise from this, has come a long way.
The town, we can surmise from this, has come a long way.
But the poor archaeologist can only wonder about the lives of the people who lived in the city's bones, hard as one might work to get those bones to speak.
But the poor archaeologist can only wonder about the lives of the people who lived in the city's bones, hard as one might work to get those bones to speak.
The town, we can surmise from this, has come a long way.
The town, we can surmise from this, has come a long way.
And that's the spookiness: We saw the ruins and wondered about the lives, and now, with these two books, the ruins are speaking and the place has come miraculously to life.

And they eventually seem to concur in their wistful conclusion that if Celebration is a bit of a corporate harlot, it yet has a heart of gold, or at least of honest brass, and does not deserve the easy contempt of its oh-so-sophisticated detractors.

I'd like to volunteer that these books have drawn some perversely unsatisfying combination reviews, most notably in the Sept. 6 New York Times , which devoted the weight of 30 column inches (by my pica rule) to admiring Celebration, U.S.A. , except for one paragraph spent denouncing The Celebration Chronicles on the astonishing grounds that Mr. Ross is a single man in an apartment without a mortgage or children, and thus had no "real stake" equipping him to comment.
